awd_titl_txt: Quantum Subgroups of the Low Rank Lie Algebras
awd_abstract_narration:
The notion of symmetries plays a key role in our understanding of various physical theories. A basic example can be seen in the undergraduate classroom, where symmetries of a system are used to solve difficult flux integrals. Classically the symmetries of a physical system are described by a mathematical object known as a group. One of the major advances of modern physics has been the revelation that groups are not sufficient to capture the symmetries of a quantum system. It is now understood that the symmetries of a quantum system can be captured on its algebra of observables (a von Neumann algebra). The mathematical tool which describes these generalized symmetries is known as a tensor category. This award will support the proposer's plans to use the theory of tensor categories to answer several long-standing questions in mathematical physics and von Neumann algebras. The award also will contribute to US workforce development through the training of undergraduate students via undergraduate research projects.

This project has two main goals. The first is to classify type II quantum subgroups for many of the low rank Lie algebras. This question is motivated by mathematical physics, where it is equivalent to extending the Wess-Zumino-Witten conformal field theories. This work builds on recent progress made by Terry Gannon. The second is to construct and classify many new examples of bi-finite bimodules of von Neumann algebras. This question is inspired by the classification of small index subfactors. As in the subfactor classification, PI will uncover exotic examples.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to study the so-called `quantum subgroups' of various Lie algebras. These quantum subgroups have various applications in mathematics and physics. Most notably, a quantum subgroup is precisely the data required to splice two chiral halves of a rational conformal field theory together, to obtain a full conformal field theory. 

Due to the various applications, quantum subgroups have received considerable attention in the prior literature. The earliest works date back to the late 1980's, and were due to physicists. These works considered the quantum subgroups for the simplest non-trivial Lie algebra, which is known as sl_2. The outcome of these early works was an ADE classification, consisting of several infinite families, along with a handful of exceptional examples. In later years classification was extended to the Lie algebra sl_3, where a classification was obtained in terms of Jacobians of Fermat curves. Before this project, classification was not known for other Lie algebras.

This project has provided several breakthroughs to the study of quantum subgroups for other Lie algebras. The key result of this project has provided the classification of quantum subgroups for all the Lie algebras sl_N at generic level. We obtain a surprisingly simple classification result in terms of divisors of N, along with a choice of sign. This greatly extends the earlier work of the physicists from the 80's and 90's mentioned earlier. 

A second key result was a new method of constructing exceptional quantum subgroups for the Lie algebras sl_N. This new method was extremely efficient, as it only required solving a degree 3 polynomial system of equations. Using this new method, we were able to construct all exceptional quantum subgroups in the sl_4 case, confirming an old conjecture of Ocneanu. The complexity of the polynomial system is essentially constant with respect to N, and so we anticipate these methods will allow the construction of exceptional quantum subgroups for higher sl_N.

The broader impacts of this project mainly concerned the training of undergraduate students in research mathematics. Using funds provided by this grant, the PI was able to hire two undergraduates for 10 week long summer research programs. The first of these was held at Vanderbilt University. Here the student produced a new software package for performing computations in the Cuntz algebra. The second student was from the University of New Hampshire. For this program, the student constructed a quantum subgroup of sl_3 that had previously eluded researchers in the field. This work resulted in a joint publication with the undergraduate and the PI.
